fields.description: This is a spin off from EUCA-3693. When in HA mode, iptables-preload are not reloaded upon failover.
fields.summary: iptables-preload is not honored when CC are in HA mode and failover happens

comments.body: reviewing

Notes:

IP Preload (vnetLoadIPTables()
is done on the primary CC from clean_network_state() duty cycle.

This is cured with implementing EUCA-3693. 

The change in Euca-3693 will now detect iptables-preload to use iptable-restore 
at /etc/eucalyptus/iptable-preload  instead of /var/run/eucalyptus/net.

If /var/run/eucalyptus/net/iptable-preload is detected when the CC starts,
the change in euca-3693 will copy the file to /etc/eucalyptus/ .
Implementing the fix for 3693 moves the iptables-preload from tmp storage to permanent storage which ensures the file is used with the system boots and the CC starts .
See dev/jpdonnelly/EUCA-3693
Cured by EUCA-3693
The is also solved with euca-3693
Fixed with EUCA-3693

When playing with /etc/eucalyptus/iptables-preload in 3.2.2, I noticed the following problem, which might be an intended design or a bug. After I put my own iptables rules into iptables-preload, the rules were immediately picked up by the disabled CC. However, the rules will be lost after a failover (when the disabled CC becomes enabled) unless I did a clean restart of that CC before the failover. [~graziano], could you comment if that's the same problem that this ticket was opened for or something else?

[~rusvika]: I just setup a test cloud, and I couldn't reproduced the behavior you experienced. IN my test cloud I have the primary and seconday picking up the rule right away (as expected), then I try to failover stopping the CC and the rule stayed on both CC. I also tried with a non-friendly kill -9 to force failover, and upon restart the CC picked up once again the rules. It seem to be working correctly for me.
I reopen the issue to ensure it gets visibility. If the above is the intended behavior feel free to close this and make the necessary documentation changes.
Thanks! (Just ran this by Tim and Vic.)

The disabled CC isn't actually picking up the file change dynamically; rather, it just uses whatever's present in the iptables-preload when it unconditionally cleans the network state over and over in its monitor thread.

I'm investigating adding a similar processing of iptables-preload to the monitor thread of the enabled CC.

I'm wondering how safe it is to change the rules dynamically on the active/enabled CC.

Obviously, the rules should stay loaded (or be reloaded) when a failure occurs.

Just resolve this issue. Basically we were not loading the IPT preload file when a service is being enabled from a Disabled state CC which was the bug. When the IPT Preload file is updated on the enabled CC, the CC won't automatically upload this "preload" list of rules. Per design, the procedure for loading the IPT preload on an active CC is to clean restart that CC. It is very important to understand that we must load rules based on "preload" rules first, followed by eucalyptus rules. Any other orders of operations could have detrimental results.

Proper testing:
1) configure a setup with 2 CC for one cluster
2) create the /etc/eucalyptus/iptables-preload file with some rules on both CC
3) Notice, using "iptables-save", the rules being reported only on the standby CC
4) clean restart the active CC and notice that both CC reports the rules when they are going online
5) Disable the active CC and confirm that the standby CC will become active with the iptables-preload rules.

Hey [~chuck],

Step 1-3 works as explained. But after restart (or cleanrestart), the standby CC loses the rules from the iptables-preload, but after restarting it again, both the CCs got the right set of rules from the iptables-preload.
Is that how it's supposed to work?
{noformat}
SERVICE	cluster        	PARTI00        	CC_36          	DISABLED  	61  	http://10.111.5.36:8774/axis2/services/EucalyptusCC	arn:euca:eucalyptus:PARTI00:cluster:CC_36/
SERVICE	cluster        	PARTI00        	CC_8           	ENABLED   	61  	http://10.111.5.8:8774/axis2/services/EucalyptusCC	arn:euca:eucalyptus:PARTI00:cluster:CC_8/
{noformat}

iptables-preload on both CCs,
{noformat}
[root@h-08 ~]# cat /etc/eucalyptus/iptables-preload
*filter
-A INPUT -s 10.111.1.61/32 -i em1 -j DROP
COMMIT
{noformat}

iptables-save on the ENABLED CC,
{noformat}
[root@h-08 ~]# iptables-save
# Generated by iptables-save v1.4.7 on Tue Sep 10 14:21:22 2013
*nat
:PREROUTING ACCEPT [824:70699]
:POSTROUTING ACCEPT [926:55580]
:OUTPUT ACCEPT [926:55580]
-A PREROUTING -d 169.254.169.254/32 -p tcp -m tcp --dport 80 -j DNAT --to-destination 10.111.5.8:8773
-A POSTROUTING -s 172.29.192.0/18 ! -d 172.29.192.0/18 -j MASQUERADE
COMMIT
# Completed on Tue Sep 10 14:21:22 2013
# Generated by iptables-save v1.4.7 on Tue Sep 10 14:21:22 2013
*filter
:INPUT ACCEPT [102:31304]
:FORWARD DROP [0:0]
:OUTPUT ACCEPT [103:32599]
:EUCA_COUNTERS_IN - [0:0]
:EUCA_COUNTERS_OUT - [0:0]
-A FORWARD -j EUCA_COUNTERS_OUT
-A FORWARD -j EUCA_COUNTERS_IN
-A FORWARD -m conntrack --ctstate ESTABLISHED -j ACCEPT
-A FORWARD ! -d 172.29.192.0/18 -j ACCEPT
-A EUCA_COUNTERS_IN -d 172.29.192.0/18
-A EUCA_COUNTERS_OUT -s 172.29.192.0/18
COMMIT
# Completed on Tue Sep 10 14:21:22 2013
{noformat}

iptable-save on the DISABLED CC,
{noformat}
[root@h-36 ~]# iptables-save
# Generated by iptables-save v1.4.7 on Tue Sep 10 14:21:16 2013
*nat
:PREROUTING ACCEPT [1776:116797]
:POSTROUTING ACCEPT [219:13048]
:OUTPUT ACCEPT [219:13048]
COMMIT
# Completed on Tue Sep 10 14:21:16 2013
# Generated by iptables-save v1.4.7 on Tue Sep 10 14:21:16 2013
*filter
:INPUT ACCEPT [23:18800]
:FORWARD ACCEPT [0:0]
:OUTPUT ACCEPT [3:1862]
-A INPUT -s 10.111.1.61/32 -i em1 -j DROP
COMMIT
# Completed on Tue Sep 10 14:21:16 2013
{noformat}

Restarted eucalyptus-cc on active CC and it caused a failover.
{noformat}
SERVICE	cluster        	PARTI00        	CC_36          	ENABLED   	63  	http://10.111.5.36:8774/axis2/services/EucalyptusCC	arn:euca:eucalyptus:PARTI00:cluster:CC_36/
SERVICE	cluster        	PARTI00        	CC_8           	DISABLED  	63  	http://10.111.5.8:8774/axis2/services/EucalyptusCC	arn:euca:eucalyptus:PARTI00:cluster:CC_8/
{noformat}

iptables-save from the current active CC,
{noformat}
[root@h-36 ~]# iptables-save
# Generated by iptables-save v1.4.7 on Tue Sep 10 14:22:54 2013
*nat
:PREROUTING ACCEPT [81:4585]
:POSTROUTING ACCEPT [20:1200]
:OUTPUT ACCEPT [20:1200]
-A PREROUTING -d 169.254.169.254/32 -p tcp -m tcp --dport 80 -j DNAT --to-destination 10.111.5.8:8773
-A POSTROUTING -s 172.29.192.0/18 ! -d 172.29.192.0/18 -j MASQUERADE
COMMIT
# Completed on Tue Sep 10 14:22:54 2013
# Generated by iptables-save v1.4.7 on Tue Sep 10 14:22:54 2013
*filter
:INPUT ACCEPT [5:3660]
:FORWARD DROP [0:0]
:OUTPUT ACCEPT [2:723]
:EUCA_COUNTERS_IN - [0:0]
:EUCA_COUNTERS_OUT - [0:0]
-A FORWARD -j EUCA_COUNTERS_OUT
-A FORWARD -j EUCA_COUNTERS_IN
-A FORWARD -m conntrack --ctstate ESTABLISHED -j ACCEPT
-A FORWARD ! -d 172.29.192.0/18 -j ACCEPT
-A EUCA_COUNTERS_IN -d 172.29.192.0/18
-A EUCA_COUNTERS_OUT -s 172.29.192.0/18
COMMIT
# Completed on Tue Sep 10 14:22:54 2013
{noformat}
*Notice* rules from iptables-preload is not present, but it's present in the current standby CC.
After restarting this CC, it failed over to the original primary CC with the proper rules.

Please let me know, if this is how it is designed.
Reopening issue, since it does not pick up the iptables-preload on first failover.

[~mdshaonimran], [~viglesias]

I cannot reproduce this. I tried the steps I provided and this works as designed. When switching the ACTIVE:STANDBY, the new active picked up the rules from the preload file but this may take 1-5 seconds depending on how fast everything switches. I used the same filters as you used.

[~mdshaonimran], [~viglesias],

forgot to mention that I tried many matrix of restarting the STANDBY first prior restarting ACTIVE, changing rules, using the clean[start|stop|restart].... And the system worked as expected and the rules get picked up.
Ok, I was able to duplicate. Sounds like for some reason we flush and rebuild without the pre-load. Currently looking at where this is happening.
Need code review of changes.
Changes reviewed and pushed to testing branch.
Fixed. After failover the iptable rules in the preload gets added properly.
